title: Exploring GitHub and Jupyter Notebook
text:
JupyterLab
At First, I thought that we were going to be using Jupyter Notebook, so I downloaded Jupyter Notebook from the App Store. This was not the case, and after I read Professor O'Donnell's Announcement, I was directed to the right software and how to access the right notebook. Now that I am working on the right notebook and interface, the tools and capabilities are very cool. I am also finding that Professor O'Donnell's guides to work through all the proper settings and configurations are extremely helpful and comprehensive. 


GitHub
Github to me at first was very tedious, and I am still not 100% sure if this blog is going to upload correctly after I upload it to Github, Lol. what I know about GitHub from a brief online research is that GitHub is a cloud-based platform that allows developers *to store*, *manage*, and *collaborate on code*. GitHub is built on Git, a version control system created by Linus Torvalds. I am Excited to explore how we will use GitHub throughout the semester. 


LLMs
LLMs are Large Language Models that are trained to understand and generate human-like language. They are called "Large" because they are trained on massive datasets, they have Billions and sometimes even Trillions of parameters. 

What I have found particularly interesting, especially as it pertains to this class, is that these models are trained by reading huge amounts of text to learn patterns of language. Essentially, these models are predicting the next word in a sequence; the bigger the set, the more nuanced and refined it becomes, therefore making it more useful. 

LLMs can:
- Generate text 
- Answer questions
- Summarization (turn long documents into short overviews).
- Translation between languages
- Provide programming help (autocompleting or fixing code).
- Conversational AI (chatbots, personal assistants).

However, Limitations of LLMs can include:
- LLMs Don’t understand in the human sense — they predict patterns, not truth.
- Can generate hallucinations (confident but wrong answers).
- Training requires massive computing power and energy.
- May carry biases from their training data.

title: Description Game
text:
Trial 1 I first tried to play this Game with Anthropic/Claude 3.5 but claude does not have image generation abilities and I did not know that. I then switched to ChatGPT 5.0.
Description given to GPT: For this first image, I would like you to generate an Instagram post-sized (1080p x 1080p) picture of myself flying through the sky on a sunny day with a few clouds, on a Griffin from Greek mythology with a lightning bolt in my right hand, and a monkey on my left shoulder. I am a 6-foot, Caucasian male with brown eyes and light brown hair. On my face, I have defined features and a low-profile nose. I want to be wearing a Toga and sandals in this image. I am 215 pounds, but have little body fat (about 10%). Try to recreate my legs and torso as best as you can, given my height and weight.
Commentary: first GPT asked me to provide a picture of myself to help nail the proportion, I did not provide it as the point of this game was to generate the image purely off of description. I am trying to test the LLMs ability to take my text and return me an image based on the data is has been trained on. The outcome was pretty solid, GPT returned me an image with all the aesthetic details I had asked for but was off a bit on my face. The image came out looking like it was painted which was not my intention but a result of my own prompt. overall I am impressed with GPTs ability to generate the image in the way I had described it.
Outcome: 
Trial 2
Description given to GPT: For this next image, I would like you to create a landscape image depicting a man in traditional Japanese clothing, poling a small boat across Lake Kawaguchiko with Mt. Fuji in the background. I would like it to be a snowy, but sunny day this time. On the left and right edges of the image, I would like you to place some cherry blossoms, half cut off by the frame of the image, and not detracting from the focal point of the image, which is the man in the boat. On the left side, I would like a cherry blossom to be falling off the tree. Orient the man so that he is moving from the left of the image to the right on a slight angle away from the viewpoint of the image. His back should be slightly turned to the viewer of the image. make the image slighty ominous, and the man should be mysterious.
Commentary: Overall, GPT did a great job capturing the details of the prompt I gave it. It hit on all the significant points I gave it to include and missed nothing.
Outcome: 
Trial 3
Description given to GPT: For this last image, I would like you to recreate this picture, which is the cover photo for the movie The Godfather I would like you to change the main character to a baby, and make the supporting characters in the image a mixture of baby animals. I would also like you to change the color scheme and make sure the medium is as true to the one i gave you as possibe, make it look like photo.
Commentary: At first, GPT returned me this: I can’t create that specific image since it would involve altering and recreating copyrighted material too directly. But here’s what I can do: I can generate a parody-style original composition inspired by the aesthetic of a classic mafia film poster. It could feature:
I expected GPT not to be able to produce the photo style medium that the movie poster I gave it had, but it did a remarkably good job. Additionally, I initially gave it a poster to model the redition; however, I have to say the GPT did well recreating the style outside of changing the color scheme. I thought that GPT would have struggled with this element.
Outcome: 
Overall I am really happy with the outcome of the test, and really shocked at the recent upgrades to the image generation skills of GPT 5.0. In the past I have created images using 4.0 and GPT often struggled with lettering, or recreating the medium I intended. I was also pleasently shocked at its ability to fill in the gaps with my vague description.

title: “Random Sentance Generation” description: “For this blog I asked chat GPT to generate a sentance using random words and then asked GPT follow up questions.” author: “Marco Firmender” date: “9/11/2025” categories: - LLM - Reasonable Continuation —
For this experiment I wanted to test the strenght of GPT’s reasonable continuation by asking it to generate completely a random sentance. I then judged the human like nature of the sentances I asked it to generate.
I started by giving GPT the Prompt, “generate a sentance for me with words picked completely at random.”
GPT returned me: “Pineapple lanterns whispered briskly as umbrellas galloped sideways.”
I then asked it to explain how it chose those words.
GPT returned me: 
GPT clearly demostrated that it can understand basic sentance structure, and seemd to have chosen random words at first. Because to me the sentance retured seemed more improbable in a conversational sense than random, but could deffinitly make sense in a fictional book or somthing creative. So I wanted to test GPT and make it second guess the randomness of the words it chose, to compare human knowledge to AI.
GPT Returned me: 
Demonstrating that GPT does understand random word selection in it’s calculation of the next best word for the sentance.
I then asked GPT to make a list of these sentances:

The endless equation jumps quickly before the endless equation calculates.
The curved algorithm calculates awkwardly although the silent whale dances.
The fractured cloud melts loudly because the endless algorithm melts.
The odd lantern whispers boldly although the golden saxophone dances.
The brisk umbrella whispers quickly while the curved cloud whispers.
The odd cloud melts softly after the fractured whale whispers.
The brisk saxophone spins quickly as the sideways lantern balances.
The golden equation melts awkwardly until the curved saxophone spins.
The brisk umbrella whispers boldly after the curved lantern dances.
The endless pineapple whispers quickly while the golden umbrella whispers.

while these are all random in word choice for each sentance, GPT does seem to use the same words over and over to generate these sentances. Testing the frequency of words chosen by GPT was not the goal of my exeriment but was an interesting secondary finding as it was very high.
Overall I think this study shows the strength of the GPT as an LLM as it is remarkably good at deciphering radomness as opposed to the next best fit for the sentance.
